item.title: A Flatter Phillips Curve
item.description: Supply and demand, isoquants, indifference, the lists goes on. Economists love curves. One attracting extra attention these days is the Phillips curve. Last week I was in Boston for the annual meeting of the National Association for Business Economics (NABE)…

item.title: U.S. housing supply and demand
item.description: In this post I want review some trends in U.S. housing supply and demand. Specifically I want to look at county level trends in population, housing supply (the total number of housing units) and house prices. We‚Äôll uncover some interesting trends. Per usual we will make our graphics with R…

item.title: Facets in space and time
item.description: My studies involve a lot of data organized in space and across time. I look at housing data that usually captures activity around the United States, or sometimes the world, and almost always over time. In my data visualization explorations I like to study different ways to visualize trends across both space and time, often simultaneously…

item.title: Everything is spiraling out of control!
item.description: I saw this fun bit of R code in a tweet by user aschinchon. df <- data.frame(x=0, y=0) for (i in 2:500) { df[i,1] <- df[i-1,1]+((0.98)^i)*cos(i) df[i,2] <- df[i-1,2]+((0.98)^i)*sin(i) } ggplot2::ggplot(df, aes(x,y)) + geom_polygon()+ theme_void()#rstats pic.twitter.com/cgNjyk405f - Antonio S…

item.title: Text Mining Fedspeak
item.description: Textmining is an exciting topic. There is tremendous potential to gain insights from textual analysis. See for example Gentzko, Kelly and Taddy‚Äôs Text as Data. While text mining may be quite advanced in other fields, in finance and economics the application of these techniques is still in its infancy…

item.title: Getting animated about new home sales
item.description: Indications are that U.S. housing market activity in the middle part of 2018 has moderated. Home sales estimates for both new home sales and existing home sales declined on a seasonally adjusted basis in June relative to May. House price growth has also moderated recently. Some folks have gotten animated about the recent trends…

item.title: Maybe the Linear Probability Model isn't all bad
item.description: The Linear Probability Model (LPM) might be bad, but is it all bad? Let‚Äôs look at some conditions where the LPM might not be so bad. We‚Äôll also look at some simple adjustments that might improve the performance of the LPM. We‚Äôll also compare the LPM to some common alternatives. Setup Throughout most of this post, we‚Äôre going to consider a world where the LPM model is the true model…

item.title: Kalman Filter for a dynamic linear model in R
item.description: As an economist with a background in econometrics and forecasting I recognize that predictions are often (usually?) an exercise in futility. Forecasting, after all, is hard. While non-economists have great fun pointing this futility out, many critics miss out on why it‚Äôs so hard. There are at least two reasons why forecasting is hard…

item.title: Forecasting and deciding binary outcomes under asymmetric information
item.description: LAST WEEK IN THE WALL STREET JOURNAL an article LINK talked about how pundits can strategically make probabilistic forecasts. It seems 40% is a sort of magic number, where it‚Äôs high enough that if the event comes true you can claim credit as a forecaster, but if it doesn‚Äôt happen, you still gave it less than 50⁄50 odds…
